member.name: M:CIAPI.Rpc.Client._TradesAndOrders.ListOpenPositions(System.Int32)

summary.p: Queries for a specified trading account's trades / open positions.

This uri is intended to support a grid in a UI. One usage pattern is to subscribe to streaming orders, call this for the initial data to display in the grid, and call the HTTP service GetOpenPosition when you get updates on the order stream to get the updated data in this format.

member.param: The ID of the trading account to get orders for.

member.name: M:CIAPI.Rpc.Client._TradesAndOrders.ListStopLimitOrderHistory(System.Int32,System.Int32)

summary.p: Queries for a specified trading account's stop / limit order history. The result set includes only orders that were originally stop / limit orders that currently have one of the following statuses (3 - Open, 4 - Cancelled, 5 - Rejected, 9 - Closed, 10 - Red Card).
There's currently no corresponding GetStopLimitOrderHistory (as with ListActiveStopLimitOrders).

member.param: The ID of the trading account to get orders for.
The maximum number of results to return.

member.name: M:CIAPI.Rpc.Client._TradesAndOrders.GetOrder(System.String)

summary.p: Queries for an order by a specific order ID.
The current implementation only returns active orders (i.e. those with a status of 1 - Pending, 2 - Accepted, 3 - Open, 6 - Suspended, 8 - Yellow Card, 11 - Triggered).

member.param: The requested order ID.

member.name: M:CIAPI.StreamingClient.TableListener`1.IsUpdateNull(Lightstreamer.DotNet.Client.IUpdateInfo)
member.summary:
It seems some streams have a 'spin-up' process that can return an all null update until the data starts streaming. We were not catching this and null updates were sometimes throwing exceptions that were logged and then swallowed by LS. I think a better way is to determine if the update is emtpy (null) and simply not fire if so.
Follows is a very simple check
